LeBron vs. Jordan: A Data-Driven Deep Dive into NBA Greatness

Henry Chukwunwike Morgan-Dibie

Follow

--

Listen

Share

The basketball world has long debated: Who’s the GOAT — Michael Jordan or LeBron James? Today, we’re settling in with the stats to see what the numbers reveal about these two legends.

Dataset Overview

Data Source

1. LeBron’s Career Dataset (lebron_career.csv)

This dataset contains detailed information about LeBron James’ career in the NBA, including game statistics and outcomes. The dataset consists of 1,265 rows and 26 columns. Key columns include:

2. LeBron’s Playoffs Dataset (lebron_playoffs.csv)

This dataset provides detailed statistics for LeBron James’ playoff games. It includes 260 rows and 27 columns, with similar attributes to the career dataset, along with additional playoff-specific columns:

3. Jordan’s Career Dataset (jordan_career.csv)

This dataset contains detailed statistics of Michael Jordan’s NBA career, similar to LeBron’s career dataset. It consists of 1,072 rows and 26 columns, with key columns including:

4. Jordan’s Playoffs Dataset (jordan_playoffs.csv)

This dataset provides detailed statistics for Michael Jordan’s playoff games, including 179 rows and 27 columns. It includes similar columns to the career dataset with additional playoff-specific information:

Each dataset provides a comprehensive overview of the players’ performances, including basic game metrics (minutes played, field goals, points, etc.) and advanced metrics (game score, plus/minus). These datasets will be used to compare LeBron James and Michael Jordan’s performances across their careers and playoff appearances.

Career Longevity and Total Impact

LeBron James stands out in career totals:

Jordan’s career totals:

LeBron’s higher totals showcase his exceptional longevity and consistent impact across multiple teams and eras of the NBA. His ability to maintain elite performance over a more extended period is truly remarkable.

Per-Game Brilliance

Jordan takes the lead in per-game averages:

LeBron edges out in:

Jordan’s higher scoring average and steal rate suggest a more intense, game-changing presence on both ends of the court during his prime years. LeBron’s numbers reflect a more versatile skill set, focused on overall team impact and facilitating play.

Scoring Machines: A Closer Look

The distribution of points scored per game reveals fascinating insights:

This data suggests that while LeBron is an incredibly consistent scorer, Jordan had a higher capacity for explosive scoring nights, cementing his reputation as one of the most potent offensive forces in NBA history.

Winning Ways

The win percentage trends tell a compelling story:

Jordan’s peak aligns with a dominant team era, while LeBron’s adaptability across different teams is evident in his late-career success.

Peak Performance and Playoff Prowess

Their playoff win percentages are remarkably close:

These numbers indicate that both players were at their most dominant in their late 20s, with LeBron maintaining his peak slightly longer. Their nearly identical playoff win percentages speak to their comparable levels of postseason success and clutch performance.

Key Takeaways

In conclusion, the numbers paint a picture of two distinct but equally impactful styles of greatness. Jordan’s career is characterized by unmatched scoring prowess and a period of absolute dominance, while LeBron’s showcases incredible longevity, versatility, and the ability to transform multiple franchises into contenders.

In the end, this data doesn’t definitively settle the GOAT debate — but it does deepen our appreciation for the unique strengths each player brought to the game. It’s a reminder that greatness in basketball can take different forms, and that we’re fortunate to have witnessed two of the game’s most extraordinary talents.

What’s your take on these stats? Do they sway your opinion in the Jordan vs. LeBron debate? Share your thoughts in the comments below!

Michael Jordan vs LeBron James: A career analysis
An in depth analysis of the careers of both of the commonly recognized G.O.A.T.S.

Rishon Ghosh, Staff Writer
September 26, 2024

I. Introduction
The debate of who is basketball’s GOAT has been ongoing for years, with fans and analysts comparing the two players’ skills, achievements, and impact on the game. Both Jordan and James have left a lasting legacy in the NBA, making it a difficult decision for many to determine who is the greatest of all time. While Jordan is often praised for his six championships and unbeatable competitive spirit, James has also garnered respect for his versatility and longevity in the league. Ultimately, the GOAT debate may never have a definitive answer, as both players have solidified their places in basketball history.
Michael Jordan, known for his 6 NBA championships with the Chicago Bulls, is often praised for his scoring ability and competitiveness. On the other hand, LeBron James, a 4-time NBA champion with the Miami Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers, and the Los Angeles Lakers, is recognized for his versatility and playmaking skills on the court.
Our aim is to try and inform your decision on who is your G.O.A.T. with all the right statistics and background information. This paper will analyze various aspects of both players’ careers, including statistics, accolades, and impact on the game, in order to provide a comprehensive comparison. Ultimately, we hope to shed light on the ongoing debate and help readers make an informed decision on who they believe is the greatest basketball player of all time.
Prime Lebron James & Michael Jordan

II. Early Life and Career Beginnings: Michael Jordan
Michael Jordan’s childhood begins in the town of Wilmington, North Carolina where he moved at a young age after being birthed in Brooklyn, New York. He was a stellar multi-sport athlete in the sports baseball, football, and basketball but that wasn’t enough for his hometown high school of Emsley A. Laney High School. He was cut from the school varsity team in his sophomore year but soon made it back as their star athlete. After high school he played in the NCAA where he led his team to a D1 championship in only his freshman year. The following years as both a sophomore & junior he was named the NCAA college player of the year which added to his early collection of accolades. The only reason his stellar college run was cut short was because he left to join the NBA. Jordan, part of the ‘84 draft class, was drafted 3rd overall  by the Chicago Bulls.
Jordan’s school picture day at his Elementary School

II. Early Life and Career Beginnings: LeBron James
Lebron James’s childhood was difficult to say the least. He was born to an ex-con for a father and to his mom, Gloria, when she was only 16 years old. Early in his life, he moved 6+ times, missing over a 100 days of school which showed that his parent(s) never paid attention to his education, shedding a spotlight on how he was led to sports. His first sport played was Football, which Lebron saw as his favorite sport when he was young. Finally warming up to his life, he was forced to move again. He led his hometown Akron basketball team to three state titles and was named “Mr. Basketball” in Ohio for three straight years. He decided not to go to college and went straight to the NBA where he was the number 1 pick in the 2003 NBA draft. Drafted by the Cleveland Cavaliers, his path to success got off to a rocky but strong start.
-Sports Illustrated

III. Career Achievements
Early on Jordan demonstrated his prowess by averaging 28.2 points a game winning rookie of the year (ROTY). He won his first championship in 1991 and went on to lead the Chicago Bulls to two three-peats in the 1990s. He then “having no more to prove” retired in October 1993 to go play for a minor league baseball team. One season later he returned to the Bulls late in the 1994-95 season to lead them to another 3 championships in the years ’96-98. He retired for a second time in January 1999. He went on to buy a share of the Washington Wizards and also became the president of basketball operations on the team. He returned to basketball again to join the Wizards and became the first player aged 40+ to score more than 40 PPG. Jordan’s final retirement from basketball appeared in May 2003.Overall, Jordan made 6 finals appearances with a total of 6 finals wins.
Totals: Six-time NBA champion (1991-93, 1996-98); MVP (1988, ’91, ’92, ’96, ’98); 10-time All-NBA First Team (1987-93, 1996-98); All-NBA Second Team (1985); Defensive Player of the Year (1988); Nine-time All-Defensive First Team (1988-93, 1996-98); Rookie of the Year (1985); 14-time All-Star; All-Star MVP (1988, ’96, ’98); One of 50 Greatest Players in NBA History (’96); Olympic gold medalist (1984, ’92).
Lebron’s first championship came in 2012 with the Miami Heat with 27.1 PPG, followed by two more with the Heat in 2013 and the Cleveland Cavaliers in 2016. His fourth championship came with the Los Angeles Lakers in 2020, solidifying his status as one of the greatest players of all time. Additionally, his four MVP awards showcase his consistent excellence and impact on the game throughout his career. Lebron had a total of 10 Finals appearances, which he won 4 out of showcasing his capability to fight to the top even without as much support as other teams have had.
LeBron James has been selected to the All-Star game a total of 17 times, further highlighting his dominance and impact on the league. He has also won one scoring title in 2008, displaying his versatility and ability to excel in different aspects of the game. In comparison, Jordan has been selected to the All-Star game 14 times and has won 10 scoring titles, solidifying his status as one of the greatest scorers in NBA history.
IV. Off-Court Influence and Legacy – Jordan

Off the court, Michael Jordan’s impact on basketball culture and his global brand cannot be understated. His influence transcends the sport, as seen through his successful Jordan Brand which continues to be a powerhouse in the world of sneakers and apparel. Jordan’s legacy extends far beyond his playing days, solidifying his status as a true icon in both sports and popular culture. The Jordan brand’s roots actually come from his parents. Not only did Jordan not begin with Nike, he actually started the deal with Converse & Adidas. Adidas was known as Jordan’s personal favorite, but when Nike offered him 250,000 – more than double Adidas offered – and a signature shoe, his parents urged him to take the deal. There are now 39 main flagship models with thousands of styles. Jordan serves as an inspiration no matter where he is to both NBA players and children alike. His skills and increasing influence led fans not only in the USA, but also across the entire world to hear of his prowess and in turn boost television viewership. Finally, by becoming a stake in the Charlotte Hornets, this showcased his commitment to not only playing but also coaching the new generation of basketball.

A public school founded by LeBron James in Akron, Ohio.
IV. Off-Court Influence and Legacy – LeBron
Conversely, Lebron has had tremendous impact, exemplified by his nickname King James, or the Chosen One. His records are seemingly unbreakable with over 40 thousand points in the regular season, additionally, James has scored 40+ points against all 30 teams.  His philanthropy has taken roots in higher education, mentoring, advocacy, after-school programs, and early childhood development or learning. The LeBron James Family Foundation has raised over 100 Million for these causes. Finally, LeBron, after struggling with poverty as a child, works towards better education for those children now. As LeBron James has not retired yet, his influence is only yet to grow and the rest is history.

V. Conclusion
Overall, Lebron and Jordan have both made significant contributions to society through their philanthropic efforts and social activism. While Jordan’s impact on basketball culture and global brand is undeniable, LeBron has also used his platform to create positive change in the world. Both players have left a lasting legacy that extends beyond the basketball court, solidifying their status as true icons in sports and popular culture. Finally, it all comes down to personal preference and interpretation of the facts. The choice is left up to you, the reader…
This poll has ended.
Is LeBron James or Michael Jordan the G.O.A.T.

Why LeBron James is the NBA's GOAT: How legend's stats, accolades compare to Michael Jordan in debate
GILBERT MCGREGOR
•
The term "generational" is often used to describe the world's most talented individuals. The most accurate portrayal of generational talents may very well be the dynamic between LeBron James and Michael Jordan.
Born just over 20 years apart, Jordan and James came within months of overlapping in the NBA. Jordan played his final game in April 2003 and James was selected first overall in the NBA Draft two months later.
For the better part of the last 40 seasons, one of Jordan or James has been the face of the league, rewriting the history books with unprecedented levels of excellence. As a result, the two are often mentioned in the conversation as the greatest players to ever play the game.
Who is the greatest of all time? The Sporting News takes a look at the career stats and accolades of James and Jordan to find an answer to one of sports' age-old debates.
SN's NBA HQ: Live NBA scores | Updated NBA standings | Full NBA schedule
Why LeBron James is the NBA's GOAT
Entering his 22nd season, James has turned in the greatest career in NBA history.
An unprecedented run of longevity has seen James continue to perform at an All-NBA level for the entirety of his career, and he will enter his age 40 season as one of the league's best players. As a result, James is rewriting the NBA's record book with untouchable marks.
After becoming the league's all-time leading scorer in 2023, James became the first player in NBA history to surpass the 40,000 career point mark during the 2023-24 season.
James' 22nd NBA season will tie the record previously set by Vince Carter and he has an outside shot of also playing in the most games in NBA history. James holds the record for most All-NBA selections and All-Star Game selections with 20 and stands to add to that tally in 2024-25.
Perhaps the most impressive aspect of James' career is that he has somehow exceeded unprecedented expectations placed upon him as a teenager. James entered the national spotlight as a 16-year-old and has spent the last 25 years thriving in it.
James' list of accolades is highlighted by four NBA titles and four NBA Finals MVP awards. While some may hold James' 4-6 Finals record against him, it says something that he has led three different franchises to the NBA Finals a total of 10 times, including a run of eight consecutive Finals appearances with the Heat and Cavaliers from 2011 to 2018.
While many other all-time greats bowed out earlier in the postseason, James-led teams have come within at least four wins of an NBA title six times. How could you penalize him for that?
MORE: Lakers expectations for JJ Redick are 'a little bit crazy,' says former coach
As for James' wins, some championships hold more weight than others. After winning back-to-back titles with the Heat in 2012 and 2013, James returned to Cleveland in 2014 and, after coming up short in Year 1, led the Cavs to one of the most impressive championships in NBA history.
The 2016 Cavaliers are the first — and only — NBA team to overcome a 3-1 deficit in the NBA Finals, doing so against a Warriors team that won an NBA-record 73 games in the regular season. James' Herculean efforts in that series allowed his team to make history and end a 52-year playoff drought for the city of Cleveland, adding even more meaning for James, a native of Northeast Ohio.
It's also worth mentioning that his next two Finals losses came to the Warriors, who improved on that 73-win team by replacing Harrison Barnes with Kevin Durant. James has come up short against some of the best teams ever assembled.
That championship win in 2016 was James' magnum opus. Leading the Lakers to a championship in 2020 was yet another title that held extra meaning.
In winning a championship during the NBA bubble in Orlando, James earned a seat at the table of Lakers lore and delivered the city of Los Angeles a title in a year where it had experienced unfathomable loss.
Set aside the longevity, numbers and accolades for a moment, and James' GOAT case is rooted in a simple argument: there is no greater basketball player to have ever played the game. At 6-9 and 250 pounds, James is one of the most physically imposing players, blending his size with one-of-a-kind strength, athleticism and basketball IQ.
His scoring and passing are both generational and at his peak, he is one of the stingiest and most versatile defenders to ever play the game. James checks each box of what a great basketball player does well and for the better part of his career, he did them at an all-time level. It quite literally does not get better than that.
NBA POSITIONAL RANKINGS: PG | SG | SF | PF | C
LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Regular season stats
James' longevity gives him the edge in total statistics but Jordan holds the edge in scoring average. To perfectly illustrate their dynamic, James is the league's all-time scoring leader while Jordan has the highest scoring average in league history.
The following stats are up to date as of Oct. 22, 2024.
Stat    James   Jordan
Games   1,492   1,072
Points  40,474  32,292
Points per game 27.1    30.1
Rebounds    11,185  6,672
Rebounds per game   7.5 6.2
Assists 11,009  5,633
Assists per game    7.4 5.3
Steals  2,275   2,514
Steals per game 1.5 2.3
Blocks  1,111   893
Blocks per game 0.7 0.8
FG% 50.6    49.7
3P% 34.8    32.7
FT% 73.6    83.5
LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Playoff stats
Similar to regular season totals, James has a clear advantage in total playoff stats because of his 17 postseason trips and 10 NBA Finals runs.
Jordan, who played in 108 fewer playoff games, is also the all-time leader in playoff points per game.
The following stats are up to date as of Oct. 22, 2024.
Stat    James   Jordan
Games   287 179
Points  8,162   5,987
Points per game 28.4    33.4
Rebounds    2,583   1,152
Rebounds per game   9.0 6.4
Assists 2,067   1,022
Assists per game    7.2 5.7
Steals  483 376
Steals per game 1.7 2.1
Blocks  275 158
Blocks per game 1.0 0.9
FG% 49.7    48.7
3P% 33.2    33.2
FT% 74.1    82.8
LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan career accolades
Longevity again shows with the career accolades, as James holds an advantage in All-NBA and All-Star Game selections. Jordan, however, has won two more championships and one more league MVP award.
Adding to Jordan's lore are his 10 scoring titles to James' one, but James is on a short list of players to win a scoring title and an assists title.
The following accolades are up to date as of Oct. 22, 2024.
Accolade    James   Jordan
Championships   4   6
MVPs    4   5
Defensive Player of the Year    0   1
Finals MVPs 4   6
All-NBA (First Team)    20 (13) 11 (10)
All-Defense (First Team)    6 (5)   9 (9)
All-Star    20  14
Scoring titles  1   10
Assists titles  1   0
Steals titles   0   3
GILBERT MCGREGOR
Gilbert McGregor first joined The Sporting News in 2018 as a content producer for Global editions of NBA.com. Before covering the game, McGregor played basketball collegiately at Wake Forest, graduating with a Communication degree in 2016. McGregor began covering the NBA during the 2017-18 season and has been on hand for a number of league events.

Home » Basketball » LeBron James vs Michael Jordan: A Deep Dive into the G.O.A.T Debate
LeBron James vs Michael Jordan: A Deep Dive into the G.O.A.T Debate
Last updated on 1 Dec 2023 by khizer.hussain

The debate surrounding the title of the greatest basketball player of all time, the G.O.A.T (Greatest of All Time), has been a topic of fervent discussion among basketball enthusiasts for years. At the forefront of this conversation are two iconic figures: LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan. Each has left an indelible mark on the NBA, redefining the standards of greatness in their own eras. As we delve into the intricate details of their careers, statistics, and impact on the game, we aim to answer the burning question: Who is the real G.O.A.T?
Career Averages and Scoring Records
One of the primary metrics in the G.O.A.T debate is scoring prowess. Michael Jordan, renowned for his scoring ability, boasts a career average of 30.1 points per game, a mark that LeBron James, with his 27.2 points per game, has yet to surpass. However, the debate takes an intriguing turn when considering the overall impact on the team. LeBron’s additional assists per game have contributed to more points for his teams, making the scoring comparison more nuanced.
Career Points and Longevity
LeBron James recently etched his name in the history books by becoming the NBA’s all-time leading scorer, surpassing the legendary Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. This achievement adds a layer of complexity to the debate. While Jordan reached significant scoring milestones earlier in his career, LeBron’s longevity and consistent performance indicate that he might extend the gap in total career points. The question now arises: Will LeBron’s record be out of reach, and could he potentially breach the 40,000 or even 45,000 career points mark?
Games Played and Load Management
The dynamics of the NBA have evolved over the years, introducing the concept of “load management.” Michael Jordan’s era saw him play all 82 regular-season games in nine out of his 15 seasons, including three consecutive seasons during the Bulls’ last three championship runs. In contrast, LeBron James, adapting to the modern approach, has played all 82 games only once in his 20-year career. The debate over load management and its impact on each player’s career adds an extra layer to the G.O.A.T conversation.
Efficiency and Shooting Prowess
Efficiency on the court is a critical aspect of any player’s legacy. Examining points per shot attempt, LeBron James has consistently maintained a high level of efficiency throughout his career. Even when facing top defenders, he has managed to stay above the league average. In contrast, Michael Jordan experienced fluctuations in efficiency, falling below the league average multiple times. LeBron’s ability to score efficiently, even against strong defenses, provides a compelling argument in the G.O.A.T debate.
Advanced Metrics
The advent of advanced metrics has brought a new dimension to the G.O.A.T conversation. Metrics such as Value Over Replacement (VORP) and Win Shares attempt to balance differences in eras and showcase a player’s overall value. LeBron James leads the G.O.A.T race in VORP, outpacing not only Michael Jordan but also every other player in NBA history by a significant margin. These advanced metrics shed light on the impact each player had beyond traditional statistics.
Playoffs Performance
The true measure of greatness often lies in a player’s ability to shine on the grandest stage—the NBA Playoffs. Michael Jordan’s playoff performances are etched in basketball lore, highlighted by his remarkable scoring average of 33.4 points per game. LeBron James, while trailing in scoring, has consistently demonstrated his prowess in rebounds and assists during the postseason. The misconception that LeBron “shrinks” in big games is dispelled by his impressive playoff performances, often surpassing his regular-season feats.
Playoffs Totals and Advanced Stats
Delving deeper into playoff totals and advanced stats provides a more comprehensive understanding of each player’s impact in the postseason. LeBron James, having played more playoff games, has surpassed Jordan in total points, rebounds, assists, steals, blocks, and minutes. Advanced playoff metrics, including Player Efficiency Rating (PER) and Box Plus/Minus, reveal a close competition, with Jordan leading in some categories and LeBron in others. These stats further fuel the G.O.A.T debate, making it a nuanced discussion beyond simple championship counts.
Accolades and Awards
The hardware collected throughout a player’s career often serves as a tangible representation of their impact on the game. Michael Jordan’s six NBA championships, all secured without the need for a Game 7, stand as a testament to his dominance in the 1990s. LeBron James, with four NBA championships and a more diverse journey across multiple teams, has controlled the Eastern Conference for nearly a decade. The comparison of MVP awards, Finals MVPs, All-NBA selections, and other accolades adds another layer to the G.O.A.T debate.
Legacy Beyond Basketball
The impact of Michael Jordan and LeBron James extends far beyond the basketball court. Jordan’s influence on popular culture, evident in the global phenomenon of the Air Jordan brand, transcends the sport. LeBron, known for his philanthropy and activism, has utilized his platform to address social issues and inspire change. The comparison of their off-court legacies raises questions about the criteria for evaluating greatness and whether it should be confined to on-court achievements.
The Unfinished Business
As LeBron James continues to add to his illustrious career, the question of unfinished business looms large. At 38, LeBron is two years younger than Jordan was when he retired. With the potential for more championships, the pursuit of 40,000 career points, and the possibility of playing alongside his son in the NBA, LeBron’s narrative is far from concluded. These potential future achievements could reshape the G.O.A.T conversation and introduce new elements to consider.
Conclusion
The debate over whether LeBron James or Michael Jordan deserves the title of the greatest basketball player of all time is a complex and multifaceted discussion. Each player brings a unique set of skills, achievements, and impact on and off the court. From scoring records to advanced metrics, from playoff performances to accolades, the comparison reveals a closely contested battle with no clear-cut winner.
